```ts
ItemSeparatorComponent?: React.ComponentClass<any> | null
```

comments.body: This was an API added in RN 0.46 that doesn't exist in the DOM API.
These are the only two properties available on the RN "navigator" object.

There are still some issues with projects switching to pure ES2015-2017, such as the lack of type definitions for `XMLHttpRequest` and `fetch`. However, it can be done if the project uses its own declarations for those. These changes are to help get us on the path so that we can not require the DOM APIs for compiling projects.

I think this one already supported a function, because that‚Äôs what the `React.ComponentType` type is for. So I think you only need to change the `React.ComponentClass` instances below to use `React.ComponentType` as well.
oh, thank you. I'll try this method.

Just want to make sure that you understand that adding your name here means you‚Äôre signing up as maintainer and will get mentions on all future issues and PRs for the react-native typings. Is that what you intended?

SectionList props extends VirtualizedSectionListProps:

@tn0502 Can you modify this line so we preserve `interface SectionListProperties<ItemT> extends VirtualizedListProperties<ItemT>`?

This is a revert. `VirtualizedSectionListProps` is also not the same as `VirtualizedListProperties`, which is what caused this regression in the first place. `renderItem` needs to be optional, or you're breaking us.

Edit: What I'm trying to say is, this is a simple revert and I'd like to keep it that way. Someone else can take a stab at implementing `VirtualizedSectionListProps` proper in a separate PR.

The "nativeOnly" map, which looks like `{ prop1: true, prop2: true, ...}`, specifies props that are defined by the native Obj-C/Java module but aren't declared in the JS component's `propTypes`. Nice üëå

Technically the Flow version (`mixed`) maps to `unknown`, but looking at [this usage example](https://github.com/facebook/react-native/blob/5ee8202b2634cfba3527a4da7f30d042fa5699a6/React/Fabric/Mounting/ComponentViews/View/RCTViewComponentView.mm#L560) it does seem like no return type is actually expected.

It would be good to modify this type upstream too, are you up for that? /cc @TheSavior
Yeah, I was wondering about that as well. I'll make a PR for the FlowType soon :)

We have the return type as mixed for many of these callbacks. It indicates that we don‚Äôt care about what you return from these functions. Sometimes people want to pass an async function (implicit return of a promise), or some other function they already have. 

If we only allow void return types then they have to wrap their callback in another function that doesn‚Äôt return anything just to satisfy the checker. So by allowing the return type of mixed the type checker is okay with it and we indicate we don‚Äôt look at the return value.
Ah I see, thanks; TS is different in that regard üëç
Ah I see, thanks; TS is different in that regard üëç

comments.body:
Above the PickerIOSItemProps should have an optional `textColor` that is a `ProcessedColorValue` to be parallel with the Flow which is:

```
type RCTPickerIOSItemType = $ReadOnly<{|
  label: ?Label,
  value: ?(number | string),
  textColor: ?ProcessedColorValue,
|}>;
```

You can extract ((event: GestureResponderEvent) => void) into separate type.


```typescript
export type GestureResponseCallbackType = (event: GestureResponderEvent) => void;
```

```suggestion
    onPress?: null | GestureResponseCallbackType;
```

I'm not really sure we should augment all props with `Value and AnimatedInterpolation`. 
I tried to find any kind of useful information in docs or react-native source code where `Animated.Value` and `AnimatedInterpolation` can be passed as a prop (except `style` prop) to narrow augmentation but I just don't see any kind of list of supported by animated values props.
Can we add this to the test? :)
üëç done
This does make it a breaking change, if somebody _had_ specified a type here, no? Having said that, I‚Äôm fine with making the change.

I'm not sure. As far as I can tell, this generic param was called SectionT but in fact, it is used as ItemT. So, essentially, we're adding a new, second param and simply renaming the first while retaining its semantics and usage.
Ah gotcha üëç
Shall we add a test for this?

I think this is an example of what is fine not to test, it won‚Äôt add anything. I think tests are important to test the types that TS will enforce through the system, but this method takes no arguments nor does it return anything. At best would it check the name of the method, but it's likely that in that case the test would also misspell it.
Good point, thanks for the clarification!
Could you add tests to cover those changes?

@a-tarasyuk I wasn't able to run the tests locally so I didn't invest more time on it. I'd rather not spend much more time on this.

I think we could skip a change to the test here: `Appearance.addChangeListener` and `Appearance.addChangeListener` is both called and there are no assumptions made that this was returning a `EventSubscription` (e.g. by calling `remove()`). I would therefore argue that it‚Äôs fine to skip a test for checking it returns `undefined`. What do you think @a-tarasyuk ?
